qc.notes: 10/10 required poses. Bright indirect light, good focus. Eye makeup present; may slightly affect under-eye assessment.

skin_type.label: combination
skin_type.rationale: T-zone shows more visible pores and a mild sheen, while outer cheeks and jaw are more matte and fine-grained.

skin_tone_fitzpatrick.label: IV
skin_tone_fitzpatrick.note: Estimated from RGB cues under indoor, bright-indirect light; actual tone can look lighter/darker outdoors.

skin_age_range.rationale: Moderate static lines (forehead, crow’s-feet), mottled pigmentation, and surface grain suggest a mature profile; indoor light and eye makeup add uncertainty.

analysis.overview_explanation: Photos show prominent sun-related brown spots on the cheeks/temples, moderate static lines at rest, and visible T-zone pores. Redness is mild and scattered; texture is moderately uneven. Under-eye darkening is present but partially confounded by eye makeup.

pores.rationale_plain: Pores are very visible on the nose and extend to the medial cheeks. Forehead and jaw show finer, less prominent pores.
possible_causes: Combination skin can keep pores more apparent in the T-zone.
Cumulative sun and pollution exposure may accentuate pore appearance by altering surface micro-relief.
Age-related collagen changes can make pores look larger.

citations.title: AI grading of enlarged pores (Dermatol Ther, 2024)

wrinkles.rationale_plain: Continuous horizontal forehead lines, visible crow’s-feet at rest, and nasolabial folds indicate moderate static wrinkling.
possible_causes: Intrinsic aging and repetitive movement create and reinforce static lines.
High lifetime sun exposure accelerates collagen and elastin breakdown.
Lower facial volume changes with age make folds more apparent.

pigmentation.rationale_plain: Numerous brown macules and clusters on both cheeks and temples with additional spots on forehead and near eyes; coverage and contrast are marked in cheek regions.
possible_causes: Chronic UV exposure from outdoor sport promotes sun-induced spots and patchy tone.
Fitzpatrick IV skin can show stronger pigment response and slower fading after sun.
Age-related changes can make existing spots more apparent.

redness.rationale_plain: Mild, localized central redness around nasal alar and medial cheeks without diffuse spread.
possible_causes: Heat, sun, or friction can cause transient central flushing.
Cosmetics or dryness may produce localized irritation.
Environmental exposure and wind during outdoor activity can contribute.

texture.rationale_plain: Noticeable grain/cross-hatching on forehead and cheeks; no obvious flaking but surface looks uneven in strong light.
possible_causes: Sun exposure and age reduce collagen support and smoothness, roughening the surface.
Pollution and dust can affect stratum corneum, increasing perceived roughness.
Dehydration at times may exaggerate texture visibility.

citations.title: Global photonumeric skin quality scale (Wiley OA)

acne.rationale_plain: Only a few comedone-like openings on the nose and small bumps on the cheeks; no clear inflammatory lesions.
possible_causes: Combination skin may retain T-zone congestion without active inflammatory breakouts.
Sweat and heat during outdoor activity can transiently clog pores but are not producing significant inflammation here.

under_eye.rationale_plain: Clear infraorbital darkening across both lower lids with mild hollowing; makeup may accentuate contrast.
possible_causes: Age-related volume change and thin lower-lid skin increase shadowing.
Chronic sun exposure and Fitzpatrick IV tone can contribute to pigmentary dark circles.
Seasonal dryness or fatigue may transiently worsen the appearance.

citations.title: Validated photonumeric scale for infraorbital dark circles (PMC)

region_summaries.summary_plain: Fine horizontal lines and moderate grain are visible with scattered light brown spots. Pores are smaller than on the nose.
Smoother than the forehead with mild lines and light mottling. Minimal redness.
Under-eye darkening and fine lines are present; skin surface is otherwise smooth. Little redness.
Slightly darker than the left with similar fine lines and smooth texture. Minimal redness.
Most pronounced brown spots and moderate pore spread from the nose. Texture shows some grain.
Mirrors the left cheek with clustered spots and moderate texture grain. Pores extend from the nose.
Highest pore prominence with a few comedone-like openings. Mild alar redness.
Mild vertical lines and slightly uneven tone. No active inflammation.
Subtle lines with moderate pores; overall tone is relatively even.
Smoother skin and lighter pigmentation compared with central cheeks.
Similar to the left jaw; smoother with lighter pigmentation.

limitations: Indoor lighting and camera white balance may shift perceived tone and redness.
Eyeliner/eye makeup near the lower lids may exaggerate or mask under-eye color.
No device-based measurements; visual cues only.
